Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Situation2: They notice a minor ethical dilemma at work, like someone cutting in line, and feel a mild urge to act.
Story: I sat across from my husband at the dinner table, watching him push his food around with his fork. He looked tired, distracted. As a wife, I knew I should reach out, ask him what was wrong, and share my own worries too. That’s what we promised each other—open communication, no secrets. But my mind kept drifting back to what happened at work today. I saw a colleague cut in line at the cafeteria, taking advantage of someone’s kindness. It was a small thing, but as a Hindu, I was raised to value dharma—doing what’s right, even in little moments. I felt I should have spoken up, but I hesitated, afraid of causing a scene. Now, as I sat with my husband, I wanted to tell him about it, to unburden myself. But I worried he’d think I was making too much of it, or worse, that I wasn’t living up to my own values. The expectations of being a good wife and a good Hindu pressed in on me, and I didn’t know which voice to listen to first.
